Document.TEXT: ADVANCE IN TURN Published on Tuesday 9 February 2016 06:31 Ten Second Review The Lexus IS offers superb build quality and, when equipment levels are taken into consideration, a value proposition that the big three German manufacturers find hard to approach. The latest Advance edition reinforces the approach with a whole heap of extras at a very small incremental cost. Get it while the getting's good. Background Lexus must really wonder what it has to do to succeed. If you wrote the template for the perfect compact executive car, it would include peerless reliability, strong equipment levels, a driver-focused rear-wheel drive chassis and sleek styling. Lexus build a car to just that formula and what does the British public do by way of reward? We go out and give our money to BMW. Or Audi. Or Mercedes. Rather than give up, Lexus has gamely stuck to its task. The second generation IS offered still higher quality and more grown-up styling. It's to this recipe that it has introduced the Advance, a trim level offered on IS220d and IS250 models that throws so much extra equipment into the equation that it makes a Lexus dealer an almost mandatory port of call if you're shopping in this hard-fought corner of the market. Driving Experience The biggest failing in the make up of the Lexus IS is its narrow and rather unspectacular engine line up, and none of that changes in Advance trim. Most buyers will go for the IS 200d and it's a solid diesel engine, but there's nothing about it to worry the German opposition. Fast steering and strong front end grip make the IS a fine car to hustle down a twisty road. The suspension is firm and rather un-Lexus like which is great for spirited driving but can become wearing at lower speeds on poor surfaces. Prominent road noise is an issue, too, exacerbated by the particularly low levels of engine and wind noise. The IS200d isn't quite as fast as the louder IS220d variant it replaced, so rest to sixty now takes 9.9s rather than 8.9s. Go for the IS250 and you'll have an altogether silkier petrol engine that packs a 205bhp punch and can accelerate to 60mph in just 8.2 seconds. Lexus's advanced handling and safety system Vehicle Integrated Dynamics Management (VDIM) is standard on all models and co-ordinates the operation of the car's ABS, Electronic Brakeforce Distribution (EBD), Traction Control (TRC) and Vehicle Stability Control (VSC) with the Electric Power Steering (EPS), providing smooth, optimum assistance as the car reaches its performance limits. Design and Build This generation Lexus IS was introduced in 2006 but it still looks a very crisp and contemporary piece of design. There's an inherent rightness to its dimensions that has sometimes eluded a few of its rivals. The taut, muscular looking bodywork with origami-sharp swage lines and very painstakingly finished detailing is sporty and unapologetically Japanese. Try imagining this car wearing an Audi or Saab badge. It's quite impossible. As ever, the interior is constructed with customary Lexus quality. Some of the materials lack the luxurious feel common to German rivals but there's never any doubt that the IS will stand the test of time. The instruments are clear and the large buttons make the various systems easy to operate. In terms of space, those in the front are well catered for but the rear seating area and boot are less amply proportioned. You get 378 litres of room in the boot compared to 460 litres in a BMW 3 Series but the Lexus counters with a sizeable 65-litre fuel tank compared to the mean 53-litres it would take to brim the BMW. Market and Model The Advance trim level builds on the specification of the already well appointed SE variant. So taking the SE as a starting point SE, the new IS 250 and 200d Advance models add a hard disc drive (HDD) satellite navigation system, rear parking camera, heated electrically adjustable front seats, front and rear parking sensors, cruise control, rain-sensing windscreen wipers and an auto-dimming rear view mirror. Totting up that little lot should tack at least £2,500 onto the price of the SE model but the Advance IS 250 costs just an extra £340 over its SE sibling. That seems extremely strong value, but as with all special edition models, they're harder to haggle a bargain on that the 'regular' versions, so try both and see what you come up with. Compared to its direct rivals, the IS Advance seems right on the money. Take the IS200d Advance, which weighs in at £24,995 (just £130 over its SE equivalent). That wouldn't net you the less powerful and markedly less well equipped BMW 318d ES. Likewise, the £26,495 IS250 shapes up very well against the more expensive Audi A4 1.8 TFSI S Line, a car with 45 fewer bhp that can't match the equipment of the Lexus. Cost of Ownership What advantage the Lexus gains in terms of equipment and an attractive upfront price over its German rivals it promptly hands back due to higher rates of depreciation. It's an inescapable fact that badges count in the compact executive sector and the Lexus IS, while a good used buy in terms of reliability, can't cling onto its value quite as well as BMW, Mercedes or Audi rivals. Against offerings from Volvo, Alfa Romeo and Saab it stands up very well. It's a similar story when it comes to economy and emissions. The IS200d Advance posts 134g/km of CO2 and 55.4 mpg, exactly the same figures as 170bhp worth of Audi A4 2.0 TDI diesel. The IS250 Advance scores 33.6mpg and 194g/km where a BMW 325i will net 39.2mpg and emit 168g/km. Therefore you'll need to make a very careful calculation when it comes to running costs in order to find out whether the Lexus IS Advance works for you on the balance sheet Summary The Lexus IS Advance isn't a car that's going to work out for everyone. If you're part of that niche that doesn't hanker after a prestige German badge but value unimpeachable build quality and plenty of standard equipment, the Lexus could well appeal. Although the residual values may not look instantly impressive, the value proposition of the IS Advance is such that if you specified its rivals to this level, you'd need to add around £3,000 to their asking price, which skews the calculation back to the credit of the Japanese car. The Advance is a model that will increasingly appeal to private buyers. It needs to as well, because the CO2 emissions of both cars are starting to look unattractive to business users. As a private buy that will be kept for a few years, the Lexus seems a better bet. Think of it as one for the long game. Ripley and Heanor News Recommends
